title: ls: don't subtract dev from production deps
body:
If a package is in dependencies and devDependencies,
filterByEnv removes it from ls --production. This doesn't
make sense, since the package is still a prod dependency.

Fixes https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/10820

title: npmlog depends on npmlog
body:
The beginning of everything:

I was trying to install `cordova-plugin-inappbrowser.git`. No problem with that...

    cordova plugin add https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/cordova-plugin-inappbrowser.git

Which screamed (:scream:) with me:

    module.js:341
    throw err;
    ^

    Error: Cannot find module 'semver'
        // ...

Then googling, I found a "try sudo npm update -g".
( I might screwed ( :boom: ) really hard just running the command, but no bad feelings :broken_heart: ... )

So, `sudo npm update -g`:

    npm ERR! Linux 3.16.0-59-generic

    npm ERR! node v5.4.1

    npm ERR! Maximum call stack size exceeded
    npm ERR! 
    npm ERR! If you need help, you may report this error at:

    npm ERR! Please include the following file with any support request:
    npm ERR!     /media/joaumg/B3CD-BAA8/friendly/npm-debug.log

Maximum call stack size exceeded... I think I broke everything. But ok...
Lets retry ? Why not?! :joy: :joy:

    cordova plugin add https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/cordova-plugin-inappbrowser.git

    module.js:341
    throw err;
    ^

    Error: Cannot find module 'umask'
        // ...

Whoa! New Error... :open_mouth:
Let's do an ugly fix...

    sudo npm install -g umask

    module.js:327
    throw err;
    ^

    Error: Cannot find module 'npmlog'
        // ...

Maybe installing the npmlog... :joy:

    sudo npm install -g npmlog
    module.js:327
    throw err;
    ^

    Error: Cannot find module 'npmlog'
        // ...

So, is there any easy fix? :heart_eyes:

Or just prune + full reinstall ? :cry:

Oh, almost forgot [npm-debug.log](http://paste.ubuntu.com/14594453/): ( 9700 lines of logging... )

title: Incorrect version of vfile cached on npm servers
body:
```sh
$ npm install vfile
npm ERR! Darwin 15.3.0
npm ERR! argv "/Users/.nvm/versions/node/v5.4.1/bin/node" "/Users/.nvm/versions/node/v5.4.1/bin/npm" "install" "vfile"
npm ERR! node v5.4.1
npm ERR! npm  v3.3.12

npm ERR! shasum check failed for /var/folders/vb/gnnlw81500xbv1j4cd9ynfv40000gn/T/npm-9325-de393100/registry.npmjs.org/vfile/-/vfile-1.3.0.tgz
npm ERR! Expected: d272e8bb5c4adc196e6181515534ff57bfe2944f
npm ERR! Actual:   ffc1b808f0d5950e0a77bbb9c477f935324aadb0
npm ERR! From:     https://registry.npmjs.org/vfile/-/vfile-1.3.0.tgz
```

Now if I wget the version and shasum it, depending on the way the wind blows its correct (seems like a caching issue on the npm servers).

```sh
$ wget https://registry.npmjs.org/vfile/-/vfile-1.3.0.tgz
--2016-01-21 13:24:56--  https://registry.npmjs.org/vfile/-/vfile-1.3.0.tgz
Resolving registry.npmjs.org... 23.235.40.162
Connecting to registry.npmjs.org|23.235.40.162|:443... connected.
HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 200 OK
Length: 8990 (8.8K) [application/octet-stream]
Saving to: 'vfile-1.3.0.tgz'

vfile-1.3.0.tgz                                                                 100%[=======================================================================================================================================================================================================>]   8.78K  --.-KB/s   in 0s

2016-01-21 13:24:56 (114 MB/s) - 'vfile-1.3.0.tgz' saved [8990/8990]
```

```sh
$ shasum vfile-1.3.0.tgz
ffc1b808f0d5950e0a77bbb9c477f935324aadb0  vfile-1.3.0.tgz
```

Remove that
```sh
$ rm vfile-1.3.0.tgz
```

If we try again, we get a different response.

```sh
$ wget https://registry.npmjs.org/vfile/-/vfile-1.3.0.tgz
--2016-01-21 13:29:00--  https://registry.npmjs.org/vfile/-/vfile-1.3.0.tgz
Resolving registry.npmjs.org... 23.235.44.162
Connecting to registry.npmjs.org|23.235.44.162|:443... connected.
HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 200 OK
Length: 8991 (8.8K) [application/octet-stream]
Saving to: 'vfile-1.3.0.tgz'

vfile-1.3.0.tgz                                                                 100%[=======================================================================================================================================================================================================>]   8.78K  --.-KB/s   in 0s

2016-01-21 13:29:01 (179 MB/s) - 'vfile-1.3.0.tgz' saved [8991/8991]
```

```sh
$ shasum vfile-1.3.0.tgz
d272e8bb5c4adc196e6181515534ff57bfe2944f  vfile-1.3.0.tgz
```


The correct version is on 23.235.44.162 and a bad version is served from 23.235.40.162

Related issue logged: https://github.com/wooorm/vfile/issues/4

title: Npm 2.14.15 and 1.4.29 coudn't handle published bower 1.7.3
body:
This issue is a result of unpublished bower 1.7.3 that did not work with npm 1.x and 2.x after release.

Node version: doesn't matter, I've tested on 0.10, 0.12, 4.1.1, and 5.1.1.

Bower 1.7.3 is now unpublished, I re-published exactly the same version under `bower-prerelease@1.7.3` but it magically works again without issues.. No idea what is going on.

Even unpublished, it is still available to download: http://registry.npmjs.org/bower/-/bower-1.7.3.tgz
Bower-prerelease: http://registry.npmjs.org/bower-prerelease/-/bower-prerelease-1.7.3.tgz

Note that these packages are exactly the same, as following script shows:

```bash
(mkdir bower1 && cd bower1 && curl -O http://registry.npmjs.org/bower/-/bower-1.7.3.tgz && tar -xvzf bower-1.7.3.tgz)
(mkdir bower2 && cd bower2 && curl -O http://registry.npmjs.org/bower-prerelease/-/bower-prerelease-1.7.3.tgz && tar -xvzf bower-prerelease-1.7.3.tgz)
diff -r bower1/package bower2/package
# diff -r bower1/package/package.json bower2/package/package.json
# 2c2
# <   "name": "bower",
# ---
# >   "name": "bower-prerelease",
```

Yet, multiple users (including me) had issues installing it on latest npm@1 and npm@2, as shown in this issue: https://github.com/bower/bower/issues/2152 It was not a temporary, os-dependent, node-dependent or machine-dependent issue. I've reproduced in on fresh install of node and npm. It worked on npm@3, but I guess npm@3 ignores bundledDependencies?

Also note that now I'm able to install both when running `npm install -g URL`, but I wasn't able to install bower 1.7.3 properly on npm <= 2 when installing with `npm install -g bower@1.7.3`.

It's sad I can't show you how to reproduce this issue, but you need to believe me it was real, I **had** to unpublish bower 1.7.3 to avoid user issues. Maybe you can retrieve previous metadata, because `npm info bower@1.7.3 --json` doesn't return anything now.

How I were able to reproduce it:

```
npm install -g npm@^2 # or npm@^1
npm install -g bower@1.7.3
bower --version
```

Result:

```
Error: Cannot find module 'optimist'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (module.js:338:15)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:289:25)
    at Module.require (module.js:366:17)
    at require (module.js:385:17)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/sheerun/.nvm/versions/node/v5.1.1/lib/node_modules/bower/node_modules/bower-config/lib/util/rc.js:3:16)
    at Module._compile (module.js:425:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:432:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:313:12)
    at Module.require (module.js:366:17)
    at require (module.js:385:17)
```

Did bower package include optimist? **Yes, all packages were bundled**

The published http://registry.npmjs.org/bower/-/bower-1.7.3.tgz contained following:

```bash
./node_modules/handlebars/node_modules/optimist # version 0.3.7
./node_modules/optimist # version 0.6.1, used by bower-config dependency
./node_modules/uglify-js/node_modules/optimist # version 0.3.7
```

Did installed bower have optmist installed? **No, it was removed by npm**

The only optimist module left was:

```bash
./node_modules/handlebars/node_modules/optimist # version 0.3.7
```

As you can see the only module left was on in dependency that is direct dependency of bower (i.e. handlebars). The other dependencies (optimist, uglify-js, and others) were removed, probably because they were not direct dependencies of bower, and happended to be there because of flattening of npm@3 before publishing.

What npm version did we published with? **Latest npm 3.x**

Why did we publish with npm 3.x? **Npm 2.x produces too long paths on Win, and 3.x is stable.**

How bower were released? `rm -rf node_modules && npm install --production && npm publish`

Did bower use bundledDependencies? **Yes, for all dependencies (not devDependencies)**

Did we use shrinkwrap? **No**, we only want to bundle dependencies, not shrinkwrap them

It's not the first time I encountered this issue. Please help to debug and fix it.

title: fatal: insane git directory for a private dependency in package.json
body:
Setting the scene we have created a few of our own modules for our front end development and these are stored within our own git repository sitting under Visual Studio Team Services. A .NET Web application then tried to make use of these modules as dependencies though the process is falling over at the build stage I think due to the directly naming convention. We are working entirely on windows OS as well just for full clarity.

So within package.json we have:
"devDependencies": {
    "module": "git+https://username:<auth_token_50 chars>@<account>.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/_git/module",

On executing a build, the npm process starts off and finally gets to the step of getting the latest code for this module, hence it looks at performing a git clone as follows:
git clone --template=C:\Windows\ServiceProfiles\LocalService\AppData\Roaming\npm-cache\_git-remotes\_templates --mirror https://username:<auth_token_50 chars>@<account>.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/_git/module C:\Windows\ServiceProfiles\LocalService\AppData\Roaming\npm-cache\_git-remotes\https-username-<auth_token_50 chars>-<account>-visualstudio-com-DefaultCollection-git-module-291122e2

This is causing a fatal error: fatal: insane git directory C:/Windows/ServiceProfiles/LocalService/AppData/Roaming/npm-cache/_git-remotes/https-username-<auth_token_50 chars>-<account>-visualstudio-com-DefaultCollection-git-module-291122e2

I cannot find and detail on ways to get around this, maybe there is an option to only use the module name as the folder rather than the entire dependency url as the folder name. Any help would be appreciated.

I apologise if this is not the correct place to ask this though running low on ideas.
Thanks
Mark

body:

title: shasum error installing  package
body:
Lately I'm having problems trying to install packages that I published myself. The specific error that I get is that the shasum check fails similar to other errors already reported here like #1751, #2701, #7991, #9559. I believe that the problem cannot be reproduced consitently and, in fact, my workaround until now has been to publish a new release of the package to skip the one with the shasum problems. However, I've just had the same problem in two consecutive releases of the same package, so I thought it was worth reporting the problem.

As you'll see in the `npm-debug.log` content below I'm using node 5.4.0, npm 3.5.3 (I upgraded from the version included in node by default) and the package name is `promisify-function`. Anyway, note that the package was published using node 5.4.1 and npm 3.3.12 in a [travis job](https://travis-ci.org/jcollado/promisify-function/jobs/103570879) as part of the `semantic-release` npm script that includes a call to `npm publish`.

I've tried to follow the advice found in other issues. In particular `npm cache clean`, but doesn't fix the problem for me. Another check I've done is trying to get the package `.tgz` and check the shasum in the command line with:
```bash
wget -q -O - https://registry.npmjs.org/promisify-function/-/promisify-function-1.2.0.tgz | shasum
```

Weirdly enough for `1.2.0` I get what `npm install` says is the expected value rather than the actual value. However, if I try with `1.1.3`, what I get is the actual value according to `npm install` instead of the expected one.

If you need further information, please let me know. Thanks.

title: Do not call magic license values SPDX expressions
body:
This tiny PR corrects a false statement in the `license` section of the `package.json` doc page.

I must have missed this when we introduced the `SEE LICENSE IN <file>` magic value for `license`. The doc page says that such string values are valid SPDX expressions. They aren't. Rather, they're npm-specific magic values.

title: When moving bin files between global versions, Maximum call stack size exceeded
body:
I put the details in here:

https://gist.github.com/natew/2931e46df9b5c003ac40

Steps to reproduce:

```
npm install -g flint@1.3.133
npm install -g flint
```

Affects a fair portion of our early users, we're getting a lot of help requests in our chat mostly because the error message is confusing.

Related to https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/9633
